title: German submarine U-1161
text:
German submarine "U-1161" was a <a href="Type%20VII%20U-boat">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
She was ordered on 25 August 1941, and was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 27 October 1943 at <a href="Danziger%20Werft">Danziger Werft</a> AG, <a href="Danzig">Danzig</a>, as yard number 133. She was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 8 May 1943 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> under the command of "<a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a>" Karl-Heinz Raabe on 25 August 1943.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-1161" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">SSW</a> GU 343/38-8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-1161" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es or 26 TMA <a href="Naval%20mines">mines</a>, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, (220 rounds), one <a href="3.7%20cm%20Flak%2018/36/37/43">Flak M42</a> and two twin <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft guns. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between 44 — 52 men.
Service history.
"U-1161" was originally handed over to <a href="Italian%20Empire">Italy</a> and renamed "S 8" in exchange for transport submarines. However, with Italy's surrender on 8 September 1943 the Kriegsmarine took the boat back over on 10 September 1943 at <a href="Gotenhafen">Gotenhafen</a> and recommissioned her on 27 September 1943.
"U-1161" was <a href="Scuttling">scuttled</a> near <a href="Flensburg">Flensburg</a>, in <a href="Flensburg%20Firth">Kupfermühle Bay</a>, on 5 May 1945, as part of <a href="Operation%20Regenbogen%20%28U-boat%29">Operation Regenbogen</a>. Her wreck was raised and broken up.
